title-group.article-title: Ovarian germline stem cell dedifferentiation is cytoneme-dependent

abstract.p: Progenitor cell dedifferentiation is important for stem cell maintenance during tissue repair and age-related stem cell decline. Here, we use Drosophila ovarian germ cells as a model to study the role of cytonemes in BMP signalling-directed dedifferentiation to germline stem cells. We provide evidence that differentiating germ cell cysts extend cytonemes towards the niche during dedifferentiation to reactivate BMP signalling. We show that the Enabled (Ena) actin polymerase is localised to the tips of germ cell cytonemes and is necessary for robust cytoneme formation, as its mislocalisation reduces the frequency, length and directionality of cytonemes. Furthermore, specifically perturbing cytoneme function through Ena mislocalisation reduces germ cell BMP responsiveness and the ability of differentiating cysts to dedifferentiate. We discuss how cytonemes may be widely used by differentiating cells to re-establish niche contact and signal responsiveness following stem cell loss, promoting robust dedifferentiation of stem cells in diverse contexts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The germline stem cell (GSC) niche is composed of specialised somatic cells, including cap cells (CpCs) and escort cells (ECs), which provide self-renewal signals to support 2-3 GSCs per germarium (Xie and Spradling 2000; Kirilly and Xie 2007). GSCs undergo asymmetric division to form one GSC, which remains in the niche, and one daughter cystoblast (CB) which leaves the niche and undergoes differentiation. The key signal promoting stem cell identity is Bone Morphogenic Protein (BMP) signalling, driven primarily through the ligands Decapentaplegic (Dpp) and Glass Bottom Boat (Gbb), resulting in phosphorylation of the transcription factor Mad (Xie and Spradling 1998; Song et al. 2004). In addition, GSCs are anchored to the CpCs through E-Cadherin (Ecad) mediated cell adhesion at adherens junctions. (Song et al. 2002). GSCs are therefore identifiable by their anterior localisation, high pMad levels, and the presence of the spectrosome, a germline-specific Spectrin-rich endomembrane organelle that becomes a branched structure (fusome) in more developed cysts (Figure 1A). BMP signalling silences the transcription of the differentiation master gene, bag of marbles (bam) (Chen and McKearin 2003; Song et al. 2004). Upon GSC division, the daughter cell that exits the niche has reduced pMad and upregulates bam expression, triggering germline differentiation to a CB (McKearin and Spradling 1990; McKearin and Ohlstein 1995). A single CB undergoes four rounds of mitosis with incomplete cytokinesis to form 2-, 4-, 8- and 16-cell cysts (cc) with interconnected fusomes (Lin et al. 1994; de Cuevas and Spradling 1998).

Restricted access to BMP is an important regulatory step that limits stem cell identity to those cells in direct contact with the niche. GSC-niche signalling is mediated in part by cytonemes, actin-based extensions which project toward and from signalling centres (Ramirez-Weber and Kornberg 1999). It has been shown that early germ cells (GCs) form actin-rich projections and GSCs extend cytonemes to probe the niche and access Dally-bound Dpp to promote BMP signal transduction. Dpp signalling induces the formation of more stable microtubule enriched cytosensors, which also receive the BMP signal but provide feedback inhibition through signal suppression (Wilcockson and Ashe 2019). Short cytonemes mediating Hedgehog (Hh) distribution have also been detected in the germline niche emanating from Hh-producing CpCs toward receiving ECs (Rojas-Rios et al. 2012). Thus, cytonemes play an integral role in cell communication in the ovarian germline.

Many factors, particularly those associated with the actin cytoskeleton, have been identified as regulators of cytoneme formation (Daly et al. 2022). Enabled (Ena), an actin polymerase, is associated with filopodia extension in many cellular contexts (Bear et al. 2002; Lebrand et al. 2004; Mejillano et al. 2004; Barzik et al. 2005). Ena localises to the tips of lamellipodia and filopodia (Rottner et al. 1999; Bear et al. 2000; Bear et al. 2002; Svitkina et al. 2003), where it recruits Profilin/actin complexes to enhance F-actin polymerization (Kang et al. 1997; Pasic et al. 2008) and filopodia formation (Schirenbeck et al. 2006; Applewhite et al. 2007). In addition, Ena localises to focal adhesions (Reinhard et al. 1995; Gertler et al. 1996) and adherens junctions (Scott et al. 2006). In the latter, Ena plays a role in Ecad localisation (Sano et al. 2012) and in cytoskeletal regulation at Ecad contact sites (Scott et al. 2006). Ena is therefore an attractive candidate that could regulate GSC cytoneme formation and niche interaction.

It has previously been shown that transient induction of bam expression using a heatshock (HS)-inducible transgene, hs-bam, causes complete loss of GSCs from the niche through Bam-induced differentiation within 24 hrs (Ohlstein and McKearin 1997). Following this, over the course of a few days, GCs can recolonise the niche and fully recover GSC loss. This is driven by cyst dedifferentiation, resulting in gradual cyst breakdown to form single cells (Kai and Spradling 2004). Here, we used this system to test the role of cytonemes in mediating BMP-dependent dedifferentiation. We show that Ena regulates GC cytoneme formation and its loss-of-function reduces the robustness of cytoneme formation. Disrupting cytoneme formation significantly reduces GC responsiveness to BMP signalling and thus precludes GC dedifferentiation and niche recolonisation.

sec.title: Early cysts can dedifferentiate to recolonise an empty GSC niche
sec.p: To investigate a role for cytonemes in GSC dedifferentiation, we first established the timeline of BMP responsiveness and dedifferentiation using a previously described assay (Kai and Spradling 2003; Kai and Spradling 2004). We transiently induced expression of the differentiation factor bam throughout the germarium using a hs-bam transgene. The number of pMad positive early GCs was visualised in the days post-HS (dpHS) to quantify the level of dedifferentiation and recovery of niche-associated GSCs. The presence of pMad indicates that the cells are responding to niche derived Dpp signalling. A transgene with the bam promoter driving GFP (Chen and McKearin 2003) was also used to mark Bam positive differentiating cells. Pre-HS, pMad positive GSCs can be identified by the presence of an anteriorly localised spectrosome (visualised by ɑSpectrin staining) associated with niche CpCs (Figure 1A, B). GFP is detected in differentiating CBs and developing cysts located more posteriorly (Figure 1B).

One dpHS, pMad and spectrosome positive GSCs are absent and GFP can be detected in the cells directly adjacent to the niche with branched fusomes (Figure 1C, H). This indicates that GSCs and early CBs have been lost due to differentiation (Figure 1A). Indeed, almost all germaria contain pMad-negative cysts (Figure 1H; 1 dpHS cf day 0 pre-HS). At 3 dpHS, while ~60% of germaria still only contain differentiated cells (Figure D), ~40% now contain pMad-positive and GFP-negative cells adjacent to the niche, consistent with dedifferentiation (Figure 1E). The pMad accumulation is either associated with a spectrosome-containing GSC in direct contact with the niche, or a cyst containing a branched fusome (Figure 1H). Within these pMad positive cysts (typically at the 4cc stage) only the cells which are in direct contact with the CpCs, the source of secreted Dpp, are pMad positive (Figure 1I, J). Fusome thinning and scission, which are associated with cyst breakdown during dedifferentiation (Kai and Spradling 2004), are also evident at the 4 cc stage.

By 6 dpHS, the majority of germaria continue to display a lack of dedifferentiation such that all early GCs are lost, and only later stage cysts are present (Figure 1F, H). This suggests that after 3 dpHS there is no further dedifferentiation of cysts. However, in germaria where dedifferentiation has occurred, pMad- and spectrosome-positive GSCs are detected in the niche (Figure 1G). The proportion of germaria with pMad-positive GSCs that have dedifferentiated is highest at 6 dpHS (Figure 1H). Together, these data show that this post-HS time course allows us to capture different events during GC dedifferentiation, including the ability of cysts to respond to Dpp signalling, followed by cyst breakdown, and the recolonisation of the germline stem cell niche.

sec.title: Dedifferentiating GCs extend cytonemes during niche recolonisation
sec.p: As we previously showed that actin- and tubulin-based cytonemes enable GSCs to access niche Dpp (Wilcockson and Ashe 2019), we used the dedifferentiation assay to test whether cytonemes play a role in the dedifferentiation of early cysts by enabling access to niche derived Dpp. To visualise cytonemes during dedifferentiation, we used a LifeAct-GFP reporter driven by nosGAL4VP16 in GCs 3 and 4 dpHS. Pre-HS control germaria were also studied, which contain GSCs with niche directed cytonemes (Figure 2A).

Post-HS, germaria in various stages of dedifferentiation were identified. Some germaria have only early or late cysts remaining and lack cytonemes (Figure S1A, B). In contrast, other germaria show pMad-negative early cyst cells extending cytonemes toward the niche (Figure 2B, S1D). In some germaria with cysts, extra somatic cells are found to accumulate in the niche (Figure 2B, S1A, B), some of which are pMad-positive indicating that they are receiving BMP signalling. This is consistent with a previous report of somatic escort cells and follicle cell progenitors populating the niche after GSC loss following hs-bam expression (Kai and Spradling 2003). We speculate that accumulation of non-germline cells in the niche can block access for the differentiating cysts preventing them from reoccupying the niche (see Discussion).

We also observed germaria containing cysts with low level pMad and short, niche-directed cytonemes (Figure S1C), as well as germaria in which GSCs have recolonised the niche (Figure 2C, S1E). These pMad-positive GSCs have cytonemes probing the niche (Figure 2C, S1E), as observed for non-HS controls (Figure 2A). Together, these data suggest that post-HS, when the niche is empty, the cysts begin to extend cytonemes toward the niche. Over time, if the cysts are not blocked by the accumulation of somatic cells in the niche, they are able to access Dpp, reactivate pMad and dedifferentiate as GSCs (Figure 2D).

sec.title: Ena is localised at the tips of GSC and CB cytonemes
sec.p: To test whether cytonemes promote GSC-niche recolonisation by allowing access to niche Dpp, we sought to disrupt GC cytonemes without affecting other critical actin functions. To this end, we explored Ena as a potential cytoneme regulator, because it regulates filopodia emergence, without affecting cell division (Bear et al. 2002; Gates et al. 2007). We initially visualised Ena localisation in GCs. Using antibody staining we identified Ena in early GCs and at the interface between the CpCs and the GSCs (Figure 3A). Using Vasa staining to mark GCs, Ena was also identified at the tips of GSC cytonemes oriented towards the niche (Figure 3Bi, ii), consistent with its role as an actin polymerase (Breitsprecher et al. 2008; Winkelman et al. 2014). We also detected Ena at the tips of CB cytonemes (Figure 3C) and lamellipodia-like projections (Figure 3Ci, bracket), suggesting that Ena may be a general regulator of GC cytonemes.

Ena can also play a role in cellular adhesion and we observe Ena concentrating at both GSC-CpC and CpC-CpC tricellular junctions (Figure 3D, E). However, we do not observe Ena at the GSC-niche interface with Ecad. We further characterised Ena localisation in GCs by specifically expressing an ena-GFP transgene in the germline using the nosGAL4VP16 driver. GSC derived Ena-GFP also localises to cytoneme tips and to a lesser extent along the cytoneme length (Figure S2A). The slightly less restricted Ena-GFP localisation, compared to that observed with the Ena antibody, may reflect some Ena-GFP aggregation resulting from its overexpression. Overall, this localisation suggests that Ena may be important for cytoneme extension and, therefore, a potential selective target for manipulating cytoneme behaviour.

To disrupt Ena function specifically in the ovarian germline, we used an established Ena mislocalisation construct, FP4mito. FP4mito contains a multimerised FPPPP (FP4) motif, which is bound by the N-terminal EVH1 domain of Ena with high affinity (Niebuhr et al. 1997), fused to a mitochondrial outer membrane targeting signal. As targeting the FP4 motif to mitochondria mislocalises Ena there, expression of a FP4mito transgene in vivo inhibits Ena function (Gates et al. 2007; Gates et al. 2009; Homem and Peifer 2009; Nowotarski et al. 2014). To specifically mislocalise Ena in GCs, FP4mito was expressed in the germline using nosGAL4VP16 alone or with LifeAct-GFP to visualise F-actin. Both Ena (Figure S2B) and F-actin (Figure S2D) are observed to accumulate in cytoplasmic aggregates, only GCs, in FP4mito expressing germaria, as described previously for FP4mito expressing epidermal cells in the Drosophila embryo (Gates et al. 2007). The Ena-GFP reporter was also observed to be mislocalised in the FP4mito background (Figure S2C). However, we observe no effect on Ecad levels (Figure 3F, G), suggesting that Ena mislocalisation does not impact GSC-niche adhesion at homeostasis. These data show that FP4mito efficiently mislocalises Ena in the ovarian germline and therefore provides a potential tool for the perturbation of cytoneme formation.

sec.title: Ena regulates GC cytoneme formation
sec.p: Next, we tested the impact of FP4mito on cytoneme formation by quantifying the length of GSC and CB cytonemes labelled with LifeAct-GFP (Figure 4Ai, ii). We found that when Ena is mislocalised to mitochondria, the mean GSC cytoneme length is significantly reduced by ~2-fold (Figure 4B). This is consistent with previous studies where mislocalisation of Ena with FP4mito results in a reduced length of filopodia in leading edge cells during Drosophila dorsal closure (Gates et al. 2007).

We next imaged LifeAct-GFP live in germaria cultured ex vivo (Figure 4C) and quantified the number of cytonemes on the GSCs and CBs of control and FP4mito expressing germaria. We observed significantly fewer cytonemes on both the GSCs (Figure 4D) and CBs (Figure 4E) of FP4mito germaria compared with controls. We then characterised the directionality of GSC cytonemes. Briefly, a line was drawn from the centre of each GSC toward the niche. Cytonemes within a 45°angle from this line were counted as being anteriorly localised, while cytonemes oriented more than 45° were assigned as lateral (Wilcockson and Ashe 2019). FP4mito-expressing GSCs display a significant shift from anteriorly localised to more lateral cytonemes than controls (Figure 4F), indicating that the directionality of cytoneme formation is perturbed. In conclusion, Ena mislocalisation perturbs GC cytoneme formation and those that are formed are shorter and misoriented relative to the niche.

sec.title: Ena mislocalisation impairs BMP signal reception and stem cell fitness
sec.p: As cytonemes enable GSCs to access niche sequestered Dpp, we tested the effect of perturbing cytoneme formation on BMP signalling and stem cell self-renewal by quantifying the number of pMad-positive GCs in the FP4mito expressing background. Wildtype germaria typically contain 3-4 pMad positive GCs, i.e. GSCs and CBs, whereas two or less indicates aberrant differentiation and 5 or more indicates delayed differentiation12. By 1-week post-eclosion, there is a small increase in the number of pMad positive GCs lost to differentiation in FP4mito germaria compared to controls (Figure 5A, B). Furthermore, FP4mito expressing GSCs display significantly reduced pMad levels (Figure 5A, C), consistent with reduced Dpp signal reception when cytonemes are disrupted. By 2.5 weeks post-eclosion, we observe an increase in the percentage of FP4mito germaria exhibiting aberrant differentiation, compared to control germaria (Figure 5D, E). Together, these data show that mislocalisation of Ena perturbs cytoneme formation and the ability of GSCs to respond to niche BMP signalling, resulting in ageing associated decline in the stem cell pool.

sec.title: Ena mislocalisation impairs GC dedifferentiation
sec.p: Given that perturbation of cytoneme formation disrupts BMP signal reception, we next used FP4mito to test whether cytonemes are necessary for GC dedifferentiation. Specifically, we transiently induced the hs-bam transgene as before (Figure 1A), in either a nosGAL4VP16>FP4mito or nosGAL4VP16 control background. We performed a pair-wise comparison of the number of germaria with pMad positive GCs (i.e. GSCs or CBs) 1 vs 6 dpHS. On day 1 in both conditions, the majority of GCs are pMad negative and have branched fusomes (Figure 6A, D, G, H).

On day 6, a proportion of control nosGAL4VP16 germaria contain pMad positive GSCs and a round spectrosome, consistent with niche recolonisation (Figure 6B, C). Germaria lacking pMad positive cells and round fusomes were also observed, indicative of a lack of germline recovery such that all GCs were lost due to differentiation. Quantitation of these data show that ~40% of control germaria have a significant recovery of pMad positive GCs (Figure 6G), consistent with the data presented in Figure 1.

FP4mito germaria with either pMad-negative (Figure 6E) or pMad-positive GCs (Figure 6F) were also observed 6 dpHS. However, in contrast to control germaria, there is little or no recovery of pMad positive GSCs in FP4mito expressing germaria (Figure 6H, cf 6G). Additionally control germaria have higher numbers of pMad positive GSCs compared to FP4mito germaria (Figure 6I), indicating that the FP4mito GCs are less able to respond to Dpp signalling. Together, these results indicate that FP4mito, which causes Ena mislocalization and subsequent cytoneme dysfunction, prevents cyst dedifferentiation. These data are consistent with cytonemes playing an important role in the ability of cysts to respond to the self-renewal Dpp signal which is necessary for GCs can recolonise an empty niche.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Here, we provide evidence that actin-rich cytonemes, which are present on all early ovarian GCs (Wilcockson and Ashe 2019), are both necessary at homeostasis for robust BMP signal activation and to promote dedifferentiation of cysts to GSCs. Our data support a necessity for cytonemes in promoting stem cell fitness and the prevention of ageing-associated decline in the stem cell pool. Furthermore, cytonemes mediate niche contact and responsiveness to the BMP self-renewal signal during recolonisation of the niche (Figure 7). As we only detect cytonemes up to the 8cc stage (Figure 2B, S1A), this may explain why dedifferentiation of 16cc does not occur. Recently, the changes in the transcriptome and translatome during GSC differentiation have been described, and this has revealed two major waves of changes separated by an inflection point around the 4cc stage. From the 8cc stage onwards, gene expression changes associated with terminal differentiation occur (Samuels et al. 2024). This transition is also linked to dramatic changes in actin dynamics. Waves of contractile cortical actin are suppressed in 4-8cc and initiate in 16cc to promote their encapsulation by follicle cells prior to oocyte maturation (Chanet and Huynh 2020). It is possible that the gene expression and proteome changes that occur in the 8cc prevent the cells from forming cytonemes, further committing the cells to terminal differentiation.

We find that only a proportion of cysts are capable of dedifferentiation. We observed additional somatic cells colonising the niche, consistent with a report of escort cells initially entering the empty niche and responding to Dpp (Kai and Spradling 2003). A minority of escort cells express low levels of Dpp, which can increase the efficiency of dedifferentiation (Liu et al. 2015). However, dpp transcription in the escort cells was found to be stochastic, both spatially and temporally, and only detectable in around one quarter of germaria (Liu et al. 2015). Based on these observations, it is likely that many of the escort cells that have entered the empty niche following hs-bam-induced differentiation do not express dpp. Therefore, we suggest that the escort cells colonising the niche can both form a barrier to GSC-niche contact and outcompete the differentiated cysts for Dpp.

Our data show that Ena loss-of-function could be a useful tool for dysregulating cytoneme function in different contexts. Ena is localized to cytoneme tips, as observed in the filopodia of leading-edge cells during dorsal closure (Homem and Peifer 2009). Using a FP4mito transgene to mislocalise Ena resulted in less frequent and shorter cytonemes, again consistent with the effects of Ena mislocalization on filopodia (Gates et al. 2007; Homem and Peifer 2009). While there are contexts where FP4mito expression phenocopies ena loss-of-function mutants (Gates et al. 2007; Gates et al. 2009), there are also examples where a stronger or different phenotype is observed with FP4mito compared to ena mutants (Gates et al. 2009; Homem and Peifer 2009). This is likely because a subset of cellular Diaphanous (Dia), a processive actin polymerase, can be mislocalised to mitochondria with Ena upon expression of FP4mito (Homem and Peifer 2009; Nowotarski et al. 2014). Indeed, loss of Dia disrupts cytoneme formation in ovarian GSCs and other contexts12,44-46 and both Ena and Dia also have roles in mediating adhesion, with Dia having a role in Ecad endocytosis in epithelial cells47 and GSCs12. Bam promotes GC differentiation by the post-transcriptional down-regulation of Ecad48,49 which must be re-expressed during dedifferentiation. Therefore, it is possible that disruption to adhesion could impact dedifferentiation by precluding the formation of stable GC-niche interactions. However, FP4mito expression does not appear to affect GSC-niche Ecad levels at homeostasis suggesting that Dia function is largely unaffected. Indeed, our data show that targeted Ena loss-of-function could be a useful tool for dysregulating cytoneme function in different contexts.

Dedifferentiation is critical to repair tissue damage (Guo et al. 2022) and underpins the regenerative medicine strategies that rely on cellular reprogramming to induced pluripotent stem cells (Takahashi and Yamanaka 2016). In Dictyostelium, dedifferentiation occurs largely through a reversal of the gene expression programme and is robust to genetic perturbation (Nichols et al. 2020). We speculate that cytonemes will promote robust signalling responses during dedifferentiation in different contexts. Another example where cytonemes may promote dedifferentiation is in spermatogonial cysts in the Drosophila testis. Following transient hs-bam expression, around half of the dedifferentiating 4-cell cysts had actin-based protrusions compared with only around 8% of control cysts (Sheng et al. 2009). Dedifferentiation is also associated with disease, for example neuronal dedifferentiation in early-onset familial Alzheimer’s disease (Caldwell et al. 2020) or epithelial dedifferentiation to cancer stem cells to sustain tumour growth (Schwitalla et al. 2013). As cytoneme-mediated communication between cancer and non-cancer cells has been described (Rogers et al. 2023), cytonemes may also be a useful target for diseases caused by cellular dedifferentiation.

sec.title: Fly Stocks
sec.p: All experimental crosses were undertaken at 25°C on standard fly media (yeast 50g/L, glucose 78g/L, maize 72g/L, agar 8g/L, 10% (v/v) nipagin in ethanol 27ml/L and propionic acid 3ml/L). Stocks used are listed in Table 1.

sec.title: Transgenic line generation
sec.p: To generate pUASp-FP4mito-Halo7-attB, actin A was amplified from genomic DNA from the line y[1] w[*]; P{w[+mC]=UAS-FLAG-HA-FP4mito}3 (Bloomington Cat#58481; RRID:BDSC_58481) and Halo7 was amplified from UAS-7xHalo7::CAAX (Addgene # 87647) (Sutcliffe et al. 2017) using the below primers and inserted into pUASP-attB (DGRC Stock 1358; RRID:DGRC_1358) digested with XbaI and KpnI.

pUASp-FP4mito-Halo7-attB was microinjected into y w M(eGFP, vas-int, dmRFP)ZH- 2A; P{CaryP}attP40 (Stock 13-20 The University of Cambridge Fly Facility) using phiC31 mediated transgenesis at the University of Manchester fly facility.

sec.title: Heat shock
sec.p: Flies one and two days post eclosion were heat shocked in vials containing a circle of Whatman paper to absorb condensation. Heat shocks were performed in a waterbath at 37°C. Vials were heat shocked for 1 hour 30 minutes at 37°C and then returned to 25°C for 1 hour before a second 1 hour 30 minute heat shock at 37°C. After the two heat shocks, flies were transferred to a new vial and returned to 25°C for aging.

sec.title: Immunofluorescence
sec.p: For standard antibody stain ovaries were dissected in 1xPBS and fixed in 4% formaldehyde for 20 minutes at room temperature. Ovaries were blocked in 5x Western Blocking buffer (Merck 11921673001) or 10% BSA in 1xPBST (0.1% Tween 20) for 1 hour and then incubated with primary antibody at 4°C overnight. Antibody concentrations used were 1:500 anti-pMad and 1:50 anti-Spectrin, 1:50 anti-Ena, 1:500 anti-GFP, 1:500 anti-Vasa. Secondary antibodies were used at 1:1000. Antibody sources are shown in Table 2.

sec.title: Cytoneme Staining
sec.p: For antibody staining of cytonemes, ovaries were dissected in PEM buffer (80mM PIPES, 5mM EDTA, 1mM Magnesium chloride, pH7.4 adjusted with NaOH) and fixed immediately in PEM with 4% formaldehyde, 5μM paclitaxel, 1μM calcium chloride for 30 minutes at room temperature. Washes were carried out in 1xPBST, 0.1% Tergitol (15-s-9). Ovaries were blocked in 5x Western Blocking buffer (WB) for 1 hour and then incubated overnight at 4°C in 1x WB with primary antibody. Antibody concentrations used were 1:250 anti-pMad, 1:250 anti-GFP, 1:25 anti-DCAD.2, 1:250 anti-tdTomato, 1:25 anti-Spectrin and 1:25 anti-Ena. Antibody sources are shown in Table 2. Ovaries were washed in 1xPBT and then incubated at room temperature for 2 hours in 0.1x WB with secondary antibody at 1:1000. Ovaries were washed in 1xPBT four times, including a wash containing DAPI (1μg/ml). Phalloidin staining was carried out in the penultimate wash (0.033μM in 1xPBST) for 30 minutes at room temperature. Ovaries were mounted in Prolong Diamond or Prolong Gold.

sec.title: Live imaging
sec.p: Live imaging was performed as described (Wilcockson and Ashe 2021).

sec.title: Imaging Settings
sec.p: Imaging was performed on a Leica SP8 inverted microscope with either a HC PL APO CS2 40x/1.30 oil immersion objective or HC PL APO CS2 motCORR (Water) immersion objective or a Zeiss 980 Axio Observer.Z1 / 7 with a Plan-Apochromat 63x/1.40 Oil DIC M27 objective.

sec.title: Quantification of cytonemes
sec.p: Cytoneme length was measured on Image J from the base to the tip of using the measure function as described (Wilcockson and Ashe 2019).

sec.title: pMad intensity Quantification
sec.p: pMad intensity was measured by taking the Integrated Density (IntDen) of the pMad positive cell on Image J using the measure plugin. It was background corrected and normalised to the DAPI stain within the same area, as indicated below. 32 GSCs were analysed per genotype.
Normalised pMad Intensity = pMad IntDen – (Area x Mean background)/ DAPI IntDen

sec.title: Ecad intensity Quantification
sec.p: Ecad intensity was measured on Image J using the measure plugin and plotted on GraphPad Prism (RRID:SCR_002798).

sec.title: Statistical Tests
sec.p: Images were processed using Fiji (Schindelin et al. 2012). Graphs were plotted and analysis was performed on GraphPad Prism (RRID:SCR_002798).

caption.title: GCs dedifferentiate over time to reoccupy the niche
caption.p: (A) Schematic of the germarium with the different cell types, as labelled, anterior is to the left. The spectrosome and fusomes are shown in white. The boxed germarium shows post-heatshock induced bam expression.

(B-E) Germaria carrying bam promoter-GFP and hs-bam transgenes immunostained with anti-pMad (magenta), anti-GFP (green) and anti-ɑSpectrin (grey, right panel). Representative germaria are shown for day 0 (B) and post-HS at day 1 (C), 3 (D-E) and 6 (F-G). (*) Cap cells. Scale bar, 10μm.

(H) Quantitation of the number of germaria where the GCs contacting the niche are pMad positive or negative differentiating cysts or pMad positive GSCs on days 0, 1, 3 and 6 post-HS. The number of germaria counted per time point is indicated above the graph.

(I and J) pMad positive cysts on day 3 post-HS with pMad staining shown as a single channel (grey). Connected CBs are outlined and numbered 1 to 4 in the 4-cell cyst. (*) Cap cells, arrowhead shows a fusome undergoing scission. Scale bar, 5μm.

caption.title: Dedifferentiating GCs extend cytonemes during niche recolonisation
caption.p: (A-C) Germaria carrying lifeAct-GFP driven by nosGAL4VP16 and a hs-bam transgene immunostained with anti-GFP (green and inset), anti-aSpectrin (magenta) and anti- pMad (inset). non-HS control (A), 3 dpHS germaria (B-C) with (B) a pMad negative 8-cell cyst extending cytonemes to the niche and (C) a pMad positive GSC with cytonemes contacting the niche. (*) Niche cells including extra somatic cells, cyan arrowheads mark cytonemes, magenta arrowheads indicate pMad positive cells. Scale Bar, 5μm.
(D) Schematic of the germarium niche showing no HS GSCs and a 3 dpHS cyst which extends cytonemes toward the niche and is BMP responsive.

caption.title: Ena is localised to cytoneme tips
caption.p: (A) Wildtype germarium immunostained with anti-Ena (magenta) and Phalloidin (green). GSCs and CpCs are marked by brackets. Scale bar, 10μm.

(B) Immunostaining as in (A) and Vasa (grey inset). A GSC is outlined by a dotted line, white arrowheads mark cytonemes (i and ii), that are shown as higher magnification images. (*) Cap Cells. Scale bar, 5μm and (i-ii) 1μm.

(C) Immunostaining as in (B). A GSC and CB are outlined by dotted lines. A CB cytoneme is indicated by a white arrowhead and shown magnified in (i). Lamellipodial projections are indicated by brackets. (*) Cap Cells. Scale bar, 5μm and (i) 1μm.
(D) Wildtype germarium immunostained with anti-Ena (magenta) and anti-Ecad (green). GSC is outlined by a dotted line. (*) Cap Cells. Scale bar, 5μm.
(E) Intensity plot for Ena and eCadherin staining shown in (D) across points 1-4 of CpC marked with a yellow (*)
(F) Control and FP4mito expressing germaria immunostained with anti-Ecad (green and grey inset).
(G) Intensity plot for Ecad staining shown in (F), n=29 and 23, Welch’s unpaired two-tailed t test, p =0.5942 (ns)

caption.title: Ena regulates GC cytoneme formation
caption.p: (A) Germaria expressing lifeAct-GFP driven by nosGAL4VP16, which are either control or carry a FP4mito transgene. Immunostaining with anti-GFP (green and grey inset), anti-pMad (magenta), anti-ɑSpectrin (cyan) and DAPI (blue). (i) Schematic of a GSC with the length measurement shown for one cytoneme (dotted white line). (*) Cap Cells. Scale bar, 5μm.
(B) Graph shows the lengths of GSC cytonemes from fixed control and FP4mito germaria, as shown in (A) for representative examples. n = 36 cytonemes, Welch’s unpaired t test, p = <0.0001.

(C) Single time point Z-series from a live imaging movie of control or FP4mito germaria carrying lifeActin-GFP driven by nosGAL4VP16. Each panel shows a single Z-slice (Z1- 8). Closed and open arrowheads indicate GSC and CB cytonemes, respectively. Scale bar, 10μm.

(D, E) Graphs show the mean number of GSC and CB cytonemes from live imaging movies, a still from a representative movie is shown in (C). n = 15, across 36 time points. Welch’s unpaired t test, p = 0.0005 (D) and p = <0.0001 (E).

(F) As in (D) except the graphs shows the mean number of anteriorly or laterally oriented GSC cytonemes. n = 15, across 36 time points. Welch’s t test, p = <0.0001 and p = 0.0023 for comparisons between genotypes of the number of anterior and lateral cytonemes, respectively.

caption.title: Ena mislocalisation impairs BMP signal reception and stem cell fitness
caption.p: (A) Representative images of control or FP4mito germaria aged for 7 days, immunostained with anti-pMad (magenta and single channel), anti-ɑSpectrin (green) and DAPI (blue). Magenta arrowheads indicate pMad positive GCs. Scale bar, 10μm. (B) Graph shows the number of pMad positive GCs counted in 7 day old germaria including the representative germaria shown in (A), n >100. (C) Graph shows the pMad intensity in GSCs in control and FP4mito backgrounds, including the representative germaria shown in (B). n = 34 per genotype. Welch’s t twotailed unpaired t- test, p = 0.0003 for comparisons between genotypes.

(D) Germaria aged for 2.5 weeks carrying lifeActin-GFP driven by nosGAL4VP16, which are either control or carry a FP4mito transgene. Immunostaining with anti-ɑSpectrin (green), anti-pMad (magenta and inset) and DAPI (blue). Magenta arrowheads indicate pMad positive GCs. Scale bar 10μm.
(E) Graph shows the number of pMad positive GCs counted in 2.5-week-old germaria from (D). n = 50

caption.title: Ena mislocalisation impairs GSC dedifferentiation
caption.p: (A-C) Control germaria carrying a hs-bam transgene and nosGAL4VP16 immunostained with anti-pMad (magenta and inset) and anti-ɑSpectrin (green and inset). Representative germaria are shown for day 1 (A) and 6 (B-C) post heat shock. Scale bar; 10μm.
(D-F) As in (A-C), except germaria also carry a UASp-FP4mito-halo7 transgene. Scale bar; 10μm.

(G, H) Quantification of germaria containing pMad positive early GCs on day 1 and day 6 post-HS for (G) control and (H) FP4mito. Data are pairwise comparisons, two-tailed paired t test comparing day 1 to day 6, p = 0.0150 for control (*) and p=0.448 for FP4mito (ns). Each repeat contains at least 30 germaria.
(I) Quantification of the number of pMad positive GSCs per germaria for each repeat.

caption.title: Cytonemes promote stem cell fitness and enable cyst dedifferentation
caption.p: Model of the role of cytonemes in the ovarian germline at homeostasis, in promoting Dpp signalling and stem cell fitness, and in dedifferentiation, by enabling cysts to access niche-derived Dpp.
